Judaism’s rock-solid view is that Abraham and Sarah are the de facto founders of the religion. We regularly refer to the three “Avose” (patriarchs) [Abraham, Isaac, Jacob] and the four “Eema’hose” (matriarchs, transliteration from the “Numbers” song near the end of the liturgy for the Passover Seders)[Sarah, Rebecca, Rachel, Leah]. Abraham and Sarah are the first generation. Additionally, there’s a list of elite prophets in Judaism, forty men and seven women, found in Rashi’s commentary in Tractate Megillah, page 14a, in the Babylonian Talmud. Abraham is first chronologically among the men, Sarah among the women. It is the prophets who communicate the word of God to mankind. As they were the first “Jewish” prophets, they are therefore the founders and first believers.

The Torah has Avraham as the first Jew, the first to identify with G-d and who forged a covenant with him that lasts to this day. Judaism was started by Avraham, the tribal divisions started with descendants of his grandchild Yaakov (Yisrael), and the written law, along with the oral law to understand it, given to Moshe om Mt Sinai when the Jews left Egypt as a nation.
